{"data":{"translation":{"id":"31924","language":{"id":"35","endonym":"English","englishName":"English","internalLanguageCode":"en","rtl":false,"__typename":"Language"},"reviewer":null,"translator":null,"paragraphs":[{"cues":[{"text":"Okay, now I don't want
to alarm anybody in this room,","time":25,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"but it's just come to my attention
that the person to your right is a liar.","time":5000,"__typename":"Cue"}],"__typename":"Paragraph"},{"cues":[{"text":"(Laughter)","time":9000,"__typename":"Cue"}],"__typename":"Paragraph"},{"cues":[{"text":"Also, the person to your left is a liar.","time":11000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"Also the person sitting
in your very seats is a liar.","time":14000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"We're all liars.","time":17000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"What I'm going to do today","time":19000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"is I'm going to show you what the research
says about why we're all liars,","time":21000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"how you can become a liespotter","time":24600,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"and why you might want
to go the extra mile","time":26200,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"and go from liespotting to truth seeking,","time":29000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"and ultimately to trust building.","time":32000,"__typename":"Cue"}],"__typename":"Paragraph"},{"cues":[{"text":"Now, speaking of trust,","time":34000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"ever since I wrote
this book, "Liespotting,"","time":37000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"no one wants to meet me in person
anymore, no, no, no, no, no.","time":40000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"They say, "It's okay, we'll email you."","time":43000,"__typename":"Cue"}],"__typename":"Paragraph"},{"cues":[{"text":"(Laughter)","time":46000,"__typename":"Cue"}],"__typename":"Paragraph"},{"cues":[{"text":"I can't even get
a coffee date at Starbucks.","time":48000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"My husband's like, "Honey, deception?","time":52000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"Maybe you could have focused on cooking.
How about French cooking?"","time":54000,"__typename":"Cue"}],"__typename":"Paragraph"},{"cues":[{"text":"So before I get started,
what I'm going to do","time":57215,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"is I'm going to clarify my goal for you,","time":59382,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"which is not to teach a game of Gotcha.","time":62000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"Liespotters aren't those nitpicky kids,","time":64000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"those kids in the back of the room
that are shouting, "Gotcha! Gotcha!","time":66000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"Your eyebrow twitched.
You flared your nostril.","time":69358,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"I watch that TV show 'Lie To Me.'
I know you're lying."","time":72000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"No, liespotters are armed","time":75000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"with scientific knowledge
of how to spot deception.","time":77000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"They use it to get to the truth,","time":80000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"and they do what mature
leaders do everyday;","time":82000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"they have difficult conversations
with difficult people,","time":84120,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"sometimes during very difficult times.","time":87000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"And they start up that path
by accepting a core proposition,","time":89000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"and that proposition is the following:","time":93000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"Lying is a cooperative act.","time":95000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"Think about it, a lie has no power
whatsoever by its mere utterance.","time":98777,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"Its power emerges","time":102000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"when someone else agrees
to believe the lie.","time":104000,"__typename":"Cue"}],"__typename":"Paragraph"},{"cues":[{"text":"So I know it may sound like tough love,","time":106120,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"but look, if at some point
you got lied to,","time":108120,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"it's because you agreed to get lied to.","time":112000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"Truth number one about lying:
Lying's a cooperative act.","time":114000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"Now not all lies are harmful.","time":117000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"Sometimes we're willing
participants in deception","time":119000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"for the sake of social dignity,","time":122000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"maybe to keep a secret that should
be kept secret, secret.","time":125000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"We say, "Nice song."","time":128000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":""Honey, you don't look fat in that, no."","time":130000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"Or we say, favorite of the digiratti,","time":133000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":""You know, I just fished
that email out of my Spam folder.","time":135000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"So sorry."","time":138000,"__typename":"Cue"}],"__typename":"Paragraph"},{"cues":[{"text":"But there are times when we are unwilling
participants in deception.","time":141000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"And that can have dramatic costs for us.","time":144263,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"Last year saw 997 billion dollars","time":147000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"in corporate fraud alone
in the United States.","time":150000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"That's an eyelash
under a trillion dollars.","time":154333,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"That's seven percent of revenues.","time":156372,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"Deception can cost billions.","time":158000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"Think Enron, Madoff, the mortgage crisis.","time":160000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"Or in the case
of double agents and traitors,","time":163000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"like Robert Hanssen or Aldrich Ames,","time":166000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"lies can betray our country,","time":168000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"they can compromise our security,
they can undermine democracy,","time":170000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"they can cause the deaths
of those that defend us.","time":173024,"__typename":"Cue"}],"__typename":"Paragraph"},{"cues":[{"text":"Deception is actually serious business.","time":176000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"This con man, Henry Oberlander,
he was such an effective con man,","time":179000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"British authorities say","time":183000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"he could have undermined the entire
banking system of the Western world.","time":185000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"And you can't find this guy on Google;
you can't find him anywhere.","time":188500,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"He was interviewed once,
and he said the following.","time":191700,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"He said, "Look, I've got one rule."","time":194200,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"And this was Henry's rule, he said,","time":195900,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":""Look, everyone is willing
to give you something.","time":198000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"They're ready to give you something
for whatever it is they're hungry for."","time":200400,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"And that's the crux of it.","time":203996,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"If you don't want to be
deceived, you have to know,","time":205400,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"what is it that you're hungry for?","time":207853,"__typename":"Cue"}],"__typename":"Paragraph"},{"cues":[{"text":"And we all kind of hate to admit it.","time":209553,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"We wish we were
better husbands, better wives,","time":212000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"smarter, more powerful, taller, richer --","time":215000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"the list goes on.","time":219000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"Lying is an attempt to bridge that gap,","time":221000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"to connect our wishes and our fantasies","time":223000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"about who we wish we were,
how we wish we could be,","time":225000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"with what we're really like.","time":228000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"And boy are we willing to fill in
those gaps in our lives with lies.","time":231000,"__typename":"Cue"}],"__typename":"Paragraph"},{"cues":[{"text":"On a given day, studies show
that you may be lied to","time":234263,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"anywhere from 10 to 200 times.","time":237000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"Now granted, many of those are white lies.","time":239000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"But in another study,","time":242000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"it showed that strangers lied three times","time":244000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"within the first 10 minutes
of meeting each other.","time":246000,"__typename":"Cue"}],"__typename":"Paragraph"},{"cues":[{"text":"(Laughter)","time":248405,"__typename":"Cue"}],"__typename":"Paragraph"},{"cues":[{"text":"Now when we first hear
this data, we recoil.","time":250000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"We can't believe how prevalent lying is.","time":253000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"We're essentially against lying.","time":255000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"But if you look more closely,
the plot actually thickens.","time":257000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"We lie more to strangers
than we lie to coworkers.","time":261000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"Extroverts lie more than introverts.","time":264000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"Men lie eight times more about themselves
than they do other people.","time":268000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"Women lie more to protect other people.","time":273000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"If you're an average married couple,","time":276000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"you're going to lie to your spouse
in one out of every 10 interactions.","time":279000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"Now, you may think that's bad.","time":283000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"If you're unmarried,
that number drops to three.","time":285000,"__typename":"Cue"}],"__typename":"Paragraph"},{"cues":[{"text":"Lying's complex.","time":287310,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"It's woven into the fabric
of our daily and our business lives.","time":289000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"We're deeply ambivalent about the truth.","time":292024,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"We parse it out on an as-needed basis,","time":294000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"sometimes for very good reasons,","time":296000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"other times just because
we don't understand the gaps in our lives.","time":298000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"That's truth number two about lying.","time":301215,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"We're against lying,","time":303000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"but we're covertly for it","time":305000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"in ways that our society has sanctioned
for centuries and centuries and centuries.","time":307000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"It's as old as breathing.","time":311024,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"It's part of our culture,
it's part of our history.","time":313000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"Think Dante, Shakespeare,
the Bible, News of the World.","time":315453,"__typename":"Cue"}],"__typename":"Paragraph"},{"cues":[{"text":"(Laughter)","time":321000,"__typename":"Cue"}],"__typename":"Paragraph"},{"cues":[{"text":"Lying has evolutionary value
to us as a species.","time":323000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"Researchers have long known
that the more intelligent the species,","time":325310,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"the larger the neocortex,","time":329000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"the more likely it is to be deceptive.","time":331000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"Now you might remember Koko.","time":333000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"Does anybody remember Koko the gorilla
who was taught sign language?","time":335000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"Koko was taught to communicate
via sign language.","time":338263,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"Here's Koko with her kitten.","time":341000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"It's her cute little, fluffy pet kitten.","time":343000,"__typename":"Cue"},{"text":"Koko once blamed her pet kitten
for ripping a sink out of the wall.","time":346000,"__typename":"Cue"}],"__typename":"Paragraph"},{"cues":[{"text":"(Laughter)","time":350000,"__typename":"Cue"}],"__typename":"Paragraph"},{"cues":[{"text":"We're hardwired to become

Miller, Guilford Press","text":null,"timecode":"02:13","title":"The many faces of lies","category":"article","__typename":"Footnote"},{"author":null,"annotation":"The most recent figures from the Association of Certified Fraud Examiners show that globally there was an estimated $3.7 trillion lost to fraud.","date":"2014","linkUrl":"http://www.acfe.com/rttn/docs/2014-report-to-nations.pdf","source":"Association of Certified Fraud Examiners","text":null,"timecode":"02:42","title":"2014 Report to the Nations on Occupational Fraud and Abuse","category":"article","__typename":"Footnote"},{"author":"Jerald Jellison","annotation":"","date":"1977","linkUrl":"http://www.amazon.com/sorry-didnt-mean-other-lies/dp/0894560050?tag=teco06-20","source":"Chatham Square Press","text":null,"timecode":"04:10","title":"*I’m Sorry, I Didn’t Mean To, and Other Lies We Love to Tell*","category":"book","__typename":"Footnote"},{"author":"Robert S. Feldman et al.","annotation":"University of Massachusetts psychologist Robert Feldman conducted an experiment in which he brought two strangers together and videotaped them getting to know each other for ten minutes. Afterward he asked the subjects to watch the tape and indicate when they said something that was “not entirely accurate.” Most participants initially asserted that they had been entirely truthful during their conversation. In fact, though, 60 percent had distorted the truth at least once during those ten minutes — most of them without even realizing it. In one case, a participant had flat-out lied by claiming to be the lead singer in a rock band. How is it possible to lie without knowing it? “People lie almost reflexively,” Feldman says. “They don't think about it as part of their normal social discourse.”
","date":"2002","linkUrl":"http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1207/S15324834BASP2402_8#preview","source":"*Basic and Applied Social Psychology*","text":null,"timecode":"04:15","title":"Self-presentation and verbal deception: Do self-presenters lie more?","category":"article","__typename":"Footnote"},{"author":"Jennifer J. Argo et al.","annotation":"This study found that people are more apt to lie to coworkers than to strangers. There are several theories as to why this might be the case. Some psychologists suggest that people are more protective of their public personas at work than anywhere else partly because the truth can often make us extremely vulnerable. If you reveal a weakness by telling the truth to a stranger, you’ll likely never see that person again, but if you do the same at work, there’s a risk that you’ll permanently alter your coworkers’ perceptions of you. And you’ll have to deal with the consequences forever … or at least until you switch jobs.","date":"June 2006","linkUrl":"http://ideas.repec.org/a/ucp/jconrs/v33y2006i1p99-108.html","source":"*Journal of Consumer Research*","text":null,"timecode":"04:34","title":"Social comparison theory and deception in the interpersonal exchange of consumption information","category":"article","__typename":"Footnote"},{"author":"Deborah Kashy and Bella DePaulo","annotation":"The researchers asked nearly 150 people to keep a diary of all the lies they told on a daily basis. The biggest liars were people who were "more manipulative, more concerned with self-presentation and more sociable," according to the study.","date":"May 1996","linkUrl":"http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/8656334","source":"*Journal of Personality and Social Psychology*","text":null,"timecode":"04:40","title":"Who lies?","category":"article","__typename":"Footnote"},{"author":"Bella DePaulo et al.","annotation":"Interestingly, DePaulo found that men and women "seemed to be using their lies to impress men and to Frank and Paul Ekman","annotation":"This study, which involved male participants who were instructed to lie in interviews about a mock theft of money and about their opinion of capital punishment for a study measuring the lie-detection abilities of others, showed that a nonverbal approach to detecting deception could yield 70 percent accuracy in detecting truths and 90 percent in detecting lies.","date":"1997","linkUrl":"http://web.missouri.edu/~segerti/1050H/docs/Ekman.pdf","source":"*Journal of Personality and Social Psychology*","text":null,"timecode":"07:03","title":"The ability to detect deceit generalizes across different types of high-stake lies","category":"article","__typename":"Footnote"},{"author":"Aldert Vrij","annotation":"This book presents a review of 28 studies on verbal indicators of deception. Buller and R. Kelly Aune","annotation":"The authors of this study measured the nonverbal behavior of 130 people, including strangers, friends and "intimates."","date":"Winter 1987","linkUrl":"http://link.springer.com/article/10.1007%2FBF00987257#page-1","source":"*Journal of Nonverbal Behavior*","text":null,"timecode":"09:07","title":"Nonverbal cues to deception among intimates, friends and strangers","category":"article","__typename":"Footnote"},{"author":"Paul Ekman and Wallace V. Friesen","annotation":"The authors argue that the body “more truthfully reveals to the observer either how the person actually feels (leakage) or the fact that something is amiss (deception clues).” They show that “this difference between face and body would be limited, however, to situations in which the person is engaged in deception. When there is no deception, when communication is frank, then there should be little difference in the information provided from the face and body.”","date":"1974","linkUrl":"http://www.paulekman.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/07/Detecting-Deception-From-The-Body-Or-Face.pdf","source":"*Journal of Personality and Social Psychology*","text":null,"timecode":"09:25","title":"Detecting deception from the body or face","category":"article","__typename":"Footnote"},{"author":"Henry D. O’Hair et al.","annotation":"The authors explain how “prepared” lies told by liars do a better job concealing their lies than “spontaneous” lies told by otherwise truthful people.","date":"Summer 1981","linkUrl":"http://www.researchgate.net/publication/229803617_PREPARED_LIES_SPONTANEOUS_LIES_MACHIAVELLIANISM_AND_NONVERBAL_COMMUNICATION","source":"*Human Communication Research*","text":null,"timecode":"09:32","title":"Prepared lies, spontaneous lies, Machiavellianism, and nonverbal communication","category":"article","__typename":"Footnote"},{"author":"Joe Navarro","annotation":"The four domains in the article are:  comfort/discomfort, emphasis, synchrony and perception management.

Schweitzer et al.","annotation":"The authors conclude that "participants with a win-oriented conflict frame were more likely to use deception and to deceive more egregiously than were participants with a cooperative frame."","date":"2005","linkUrl":"http://www.donaldegibson.com/files/Conflict%20Frames_0.pdf","source":"*Journal of Applied Social Psychology*","text":null,"timecode":"10:22","title":"Conflict frames and the use of deception: Are competitive negotiators less ethical?","category":"article","__typename":"Footnote"},{"author":"Paul Ekman","annotation":"Ekman describes this trait as "the near irresistible thrill some people feel in taking a risk and getting away with it. It is hard to contain duping delight; those who feel it want to share their accomplishments with others, seeking admiration for their exploits."","date":"December 2009","linkUrl":"http://www.paulekman.com/uncategorized/duping-delight/","source":"Paul Ekman Group","text":null,"timecode":"11:47","title":"Duping Delight","category":"article","__typename":"Footnote"},{"author":"Paul Ekman and Wallace V. Friesen","annotation":"In addition to discussing the concept of leakage, Ekman introduces his theory of “micro” facial expressions, which he describes as facial expressions whose “duration is so short that they are at the threshold of recognition unless slow motion projection is utilized.” Ekman explains how the face is one of the best body language indicators. “A frozen, immobile poker face is more noticeable than are interlocked fingers or tensely held feet.”","date":"February 1969","linkUrl":"http://www.paulekman.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/07/Nonverbal-Leakage-And-Clues-To-Deception.pdf","source":"*Journal for the Study of Interpersonal Processes*","text":null,"timecode":"12:36","title":"Nonverbal leakage and clues to deception","category":"article","__typename":"Footnote"},{"author":"American Academy of Neurology","annotation":"This study explains that people mistakenly only focus on the lower part of the face when trying to detect deceit, since the upper part of the face tends to carry more meaning.","date":"May 4, 2000","linkUrl":"http://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2000/05/000503181624.htm","source":"*Science Daily*","text":null,"timecode":"13:06","title":"Often missed facial displays give clues to true emotion, deceit","category":"article","__typename":"Footnote"},{"author":"Evan Marshall","annotation":"","date":"2003","linkUrl":"http://www.amazon.com/The-Eyes-Have-It-Revealing/dp/0806524456?tag=teco06-20","source":"Citadel Press","text":null,"timecode":"13:48","title":"*The Eyes Have It*","category":"book","__typename":"Footnote"},{"author":"Allan and Barbara Pease","annotation":"","date":"2006","linkUrl":"http://www.amazon.com/The-Definitive-Book-Body-Language/dp/0553804723?tag=teco06-20","source":"Bantam","text":null,"timecode":"13:53","title":"*The Definitive Book of Body Language*","category":"book","__typename":"Footnote"}],"__typename":"TalkExtras"},"__typename":"Video"}}}
